awd_titl_txt: In Situ Growth and Placement of Nanostructures by Solution-Based Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanostructures are characterized by their tiny size - they are measured in nanometers, which are millionths of a millimeter. These tiny dimensions give them enhanced properties, which have applications in many technologies, from computers to cell phones to solar cells. One of the biggest challenges in the development of nanotechnology is the low-cost integration of nanostructures into commercial devices.  Dr. Amy Walker (University of Texas at Dallas) addresses this problem by developing new methods to grow "in place" (in situ) nanowires, nanopores, nanorings, nanosheets and nanochannels made from transition metal chalcogenides, metal compounds containing sulfur or selenium. These materials are very promising for faster electronics, more efficient solar cells, new kinds of sensors and improved fuel cells. Her group specializes in solution-based methods which are cheaper and more environmentally friendly than conventional techniques. Dr. Walker uses a variety of experimental tools to study the growth and properties of nanostructures, in particular imaging mass spectrometry. This research is attractive to students at many levels. Both graduate and undergraduate students gain valuable expertise in her lab, going on to careers in the semiconductor, chemical and high-tech manufacturing industries.  Dr. Walker involves students in electrochemistry, device design, nanoscience, surface and materials characterization, spectroscopy and mass spectrometry studies. 

In this work, Dr. Amy Walker (University of Texas at Dallas) is funded by the Macromolecular, Supermolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program to develop new and scalable techniques used to synthesize metal chalcogenide nanostructures. Semiconductor nanowire deposition on micropatterned substrates (SENDOM) can create nanowires, nanopores, nanochannels and nanorings, which enables the fabrication of complex functional structures such as nanowire-based transistors. In SENDOM, a multifunctional micropatterned surface is used to direct the growth of nanostructures by chemical bath deposition (CBD). SENDOM is an in situ method that does not use complex lithography - these are significant advantages over other methods for nanostructures synthesis and placement. SENDOM relies on control of the interaction of CBD precursors and additives with organic thin films. Detailed mechanistic information about these interactions is also being leveraged to develop in situ solution-based techniques to selectively deposit and form free-standing transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) nanofilms. This research program substantially advances the state-of-the-art in nanotechnology by enabling the integration of nanostructures in practical devices.  Finally, solution-based methods such as those used in this work are becoming increasingly important in "high-tech" industries, and Dr. Walker is developing educational modules to train students at all levels in this area.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop, apply and optimize an inexpensive, scalable platform for the surface-directed in-place growth of metallic and semiconducting nanostructures. These structures have broad applications in fields such as nanoelectronics, sensing, data storage, catalysis, and energy harvesting and storage. We use mechanistically designed chemical bath deposition (CBD) and electroless deposition (ELD) reactions to deposit nanostructures, including nanowires and films, of controlled polytype, composition and structure.

  We developed a room-temperature aqueous CBD method by which to deposit molybdenum disulfide, MoS2 nanofilms with both polytype control and area selective deposition. Molybdenum disulfide has two polytypes. 2H MoS2 is a semiconductor and is the thermodynamically stable polytype. Metastable 1T MoS2 can also be prepared and is semimetallic. While the properties of single-layer and multi-layer MoS2 are well understood, in situ control of the deposited polytype remains a significant challenge. We demonstrated that 1T MoS2 was deposited on hydrophilic substrates, while on hydrophobic substrates 2H MoS2 was deposited. We exploited this effect to demonstrate the area-selective deposition of 1T and 2H MoS2, which could be used to lower contact resistances in metal-MoS2 contacts and enable their use in practical devices. We subsequently demonstrated a CBD process for deposition of WS2 nanofilms.

  Our studies of copper sulfide CBD on functionalized SAMs have exposed multiple different phenomena which we attribute to the interaction of the sulfur source with the surface. Using thioacetamide as the sulfur source, the deposition is area-selective, with preferential deposition occurring on a non-polar methyl-terminated surface. As short deposition times a nanowire forms at the interface of patterned hydrophobic/hydrophilic SAM surfaces. We term this process “Semiconductor Nanowire Deposition on Micropatterned Substrates” or SENDOM, and determined that nanowire formation occurs at the interface of two dissimilar materials if two conditions are met. First, deposition must be kinetically favored due to preferential adsorption of the chalcogenide anion on the material, in this case the hydrophobic surface. Second, transport of reactants must be faster on the surface with the lower deposition rate, in this case the hydrophilic SAM.

  We also showed for the first time that the composition of the copper sulfide deposited by CBD can be controlled through manipulation of bath conditions. Copper sulfide exists in many stoichiometric and non-stoichiometric forms. Each composition has different physical and chemical properties. Using thiourea as the sulfur-source, the deposit chemistry can be varied from CuS to Cu2S and is dependent on the bath pH and substrate chemistry. This effect appears to be quite general.  Most recently we have shown that deposition of tin sulfide (which can vary between SnS and SnS2) is also strongly dependent on the bath pH and substrate chemistry, which we also attribute to the interaction of the sulfur-source with the surface.

  In the previous project period we demonstrated the formation of metallic nanostructures using Electroless Nanowire Deposition on Micropatterned Substrates (ENDOM), which employs electroless deposition (ELD). In this project we further developed the use of bath additives in ENDOM to control nanostructure adhesion to substrates, enabling their easy transfer to produce more complex devices and for electrical measurements. Additionally, we have shown that bath additives can be used to alter deposit compositions in electroless deposition. Using thiourea as a bath additive in copper ELD, we are able to control the deposit composition from metallic copper to copper sulfide (CuS). These observations suggest a new route by which to deposit copper sulfide nanowires and other metal chalcogenide nanostructures.

  Five graduate students (two women and two Hispanic students), and three undergraduates (two women, two Hispanic and one American Indian) participated in this research. During the project one graduate student received their PhD and is now a scientific officer at Northwestern University. Two undergraduates have received their BS; one is now a medical scribe and one is a student at Arizona State University Law School. This work also led to a number of new contracts and collaborations with both companies, including Max IR Labs, and museums, including the Amon Carter Museum (Fort Worth, TX) and the Rijksmuseum (Amsterdam, The Netherlands).


Last Modified: 11/21/2021
Modified by: Amy Walker

The goal of this project is to develop, apply and optimize an inexpensive, scalable platform for the surface-directed in-place growth of metallic and semiconducting nanostructures. These structures have broad applications in fields such as nanoelectronics, sensing, data storage, catalysis, and energy harvesting and storage. During the project one graduate student received their PhD and is now a scientific officer at Northwestern University. Two undergraduates have received their BS; one is now a medical scribe and one is a student at Arizona State University Law School.
